ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: one on weeks we had it
0 hours
About 1 hour on weeks when there was a session.
none

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I'm still not always sure why we go to these lectures.
Have speakers outside of academia/ research.
Might want to survey students to pick topics that a majority are interested in.
Very interesting lectures this semester.

I think that a lot of the topics covered were very interesting and pertinent to SBS, however in some instances it seemed like the speaker did not understand the audience - especially the Psychologist who spoke about genetics and learning disabilities.

I think the talks were generally interesting. I think the attendance was surprisingly poor (particularly when the talks were not job talks). It seemed at times that the seminar was competing with other talks within YSPH which perhaps affected attendance, so that is something that could be considered when planning the seminar time in the future. I also would have like to attend some of those competing lectures, so keeping the time in mind would also allow students to attend talks of interest in other departments.

I liked the diversity of speakers. There were both researchers and practicing epidemiologists, so it was great to hear ongoing projects in both areas. One suggestion that I've made in the past is to have an opportunity for PhD students or postdocs in the department to present their research as well. It would be really nice to know what research our peers in the doctoral program are currently pursuing.Also, I think it would be best to split the SBS and CDE seminars (or at least have more of both). I actually would have liked to have had more CDE-specific seminars, the number of which were limited due to the alternating nature of CDE and SBS seminars.
I didn't feel that any of the guests were relevant to what I want to study. The man who talked about education was very good though.
I would like to see more speakers who work in sectors of public health outside of academia/research.
The topics were varied and interesting.
Speaks helped us to expand students' view of the public health. All speaks were very interesting!!
good
It would be better if the guest lecturers were more directed at SBS public health in the workforce - ie a combination of research and people working with organizations, the government, etc.
great exposure to research outside of YSPH
Excellent course that provides students with an opportunity to envision what career path they would like to take.

I like the SBS seminar series! I thought it was a really great group of lecturers this semester from across the University.In the future I think it might be nice if the seminar series could incorporate more speakers who have careers in SBS -- I would LOVE to meet more people outside of the university who work in the field (especially outside of the research field). Also, it would be a great networking opportunity for students.
some seminars are interesting and relevant

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Becca Levy  Good, they chose good speakers. Becca is fabulous!
Instructor: Becca Levy  She's great - dynamic and accessible.
Instructor: Becca Levy  I think the selection of speakers was good; I would encourage more advertising in addition to previous comments to try to boost attendance.
Instructor: Becca Levy
Instructor: Becca Levy  She was a good instructor.
Instructor: Becca Levy  helpful
Instructor: Becca Levy  Great instructor who asked insightful questions of the speakers.
Instructor: Becca Levy  NA
Instructor: Susan Mayne  NA
Instructor: Susan Mayne  I don't know who she is.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  Same comments as above.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  I'm so impressed by how receptive Susan is to student input. I have seen tangible changes in the past year due to student suggestions, which is wonderful.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  She was a good instructor.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  great

Instructor: Susan Mayne  Professor Mayne is a great instructor. I have also taken her Nutrition course, and she always answers emails, makes time in her schedule to meet with students, and is great about providing feedback. I would recommend learning as much as possible from Prof Mayne, as she is an expert in Nutrition and Nutrition policy.
Instructor: Susan Mayne  NA

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Sometimes the speakers are exciting, but overall it seems like I could go without these seminars. I would only recommend certain speakers to other students.

Some of the lecturers were very good and relevant, others were very informative but of much less interest* the lecture on the collaboration of public health and medicine was excellent; the preeclampsia lecture was also very good
Good. Would recommend it.
I like it - it gives students a broader idea of the type of research that is being conducted around the country and at Yale.
I think it's a good seminar series with a breadth of topics, and would recommend to other students.
Yes. It provides a broad survey of issues in chronic disease epidemiology as well as a survey of various measurement and assessment tools.
Yes, I will.
yes good
Great
Great way to figure out what you would like to do once you graduate from YSPH.
Good seminar series!
Yes
